projects.name: Crocheted buttons

steps.instruction: The stitches in the first round will be crocheted in a loop: wrap a loop around the middle finger of your left hand, and hold the end of it with the ring finger of the same hand.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of hands wrapping purple yarn around the middle finger to form a loop.

steps.instruction: Push the hook under the loop and pull one loop through, still holding on to the end of the yarn.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a crochet hook inserted under the yarn loop on the finger, pulling a loop of purple yarn through.

steps.instruction: Work one chain, i.e. draw another loop through the loop on the hook.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the crochet hook with one loop on it, pulling another loop of purple yarn through to form a chain stitch.

steps.instruction: Next, crochet six single crochet (UK double) of the first round, insert the hook under the loop and draw yarn through so you have two loops on the hook. Then draw a loop through the two loops on the hook. End the first round with one slip stitch in the first single crochet (UK double crochet).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the initial chain of six single crochet stitches formed around the yarn loop.

steps.instruction: When changing colours after the first round, work the slip stitches in the new colour. Work one chain stitch to change to second row.

Work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into each stitch in the previous round, inserting the hook in the back loop only = twelve stitches. End the round with one slip stitch into the first single crochet (UK double crochet) (not into the chain stitch). Tighten the loop after the second round.

Start each following round with one chain stitch. In the third round, work one single crochet (UK double crochet), then two single crochet (UK double crochet) into one stitch in the previous round = eighteen stitches.
steps.technique: chain stitch, single crochet (UK double), increasing

steps.instruction: In the fourth round, work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into stitch = twenty-four stitches.
In the fifth round, work two single crochet (UK double crochet) into every fourth stitch = thirty stitches.
In the sixth round, increase in every fifth stitch, and in the seventh round in every sixth stitch = forty-two stitches.

Start the next round on the back of the button. Secure yarn and place the shank button on the back of the work. Working in spirals (no chain between rounds), decrease two single crochet (UK double crochet) together (see page 11).

tips: Try sewing these onto cards to make the perfect home-made gift.
projects.finished_product_description: Various crocheted buttons, some with intricate patterns and multiple colors, suitable for embellishing cards or other crafts.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram 1: Close-up photo of hands wrapping purple yarn around the middle finger to form a loop, with the end held by the ring finger.
Diagram 2: Close-up photo of a crochet hook inserted under the yarn loop on the finger, pulling a loop of purple yarn through.
Diagram 3: Close-up photo of the crochet hook with one loop on it, pulling another loop of purple yarn through to form a chain stitch.
Diagram 4: Close-up photo showing the initial chain of six single crochet stitches formed around the yarn loop on the finger.

Overall image: A flat lay composition featuring various vintage buttons (mother-of-pearl, black plastic, metal with designs) and boxes, interspersed with several finished crocheted buttons. Some crocheted buttons are solid pink/white, some are multi-colored with concentric circles, and some are shaped like flowers. Several crocheted buttons are displayed on decorative cards, suggesting their use as embellishments for gifts. One card has the German text 'EIN KNOPF FÜR DICH' (A BUTTON FOR YOU).

projects.name: Button A

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in white
very fine crochet yarn in magenta

steps.instruction: Crochet the first to seventh rounds (see page 62). Start with white and alternate the colour at the end of each round. Work the slip stitch in the new colour at the end of the round. Work the back in white (see page 62).

projects.finished_product_description: A crocheted button with alternating colors.

projects.name: Button B

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in white
very fine crochet yarn in magenta

steps.instruction: As with button A, but start with magenta and work only five rounds for the front, then insert the little shank button and work the back in white (see page 62).

projects.finished_product_description: A crocheted button starting with magenta, with a shank button inserted.

projects.name: Button C

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in white
very fine crochet yarn in magenta

steps.instruction: Crochet the first to seventh rounds (see page 62). Start with white, and in the third round work one stitch in magenta after the increase. Finish the previous stitch (= increase) in magenta. Finish the next stitch in magenta with white. In the sixth round, again start coloured stitches in magenta. Work every third (= stitch after increase) and sixth stitch as described in magenta. Work the back in white (see page 62).

projects.finished_product_description: A crocheted button with specific color changes in the third and sixth rounds.

projects.name: Button D

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in magenta
very fine crochet yarn in white

steps.instruction: Crochet the first to seventh rounds in magenta (see page 62). Increase the loop on the hook, but do not cut. Sew French knots (see page 38) in white. The rounds and increases serve as points of orientation when arranging the stitches. Secure the ends of the white threads and the starting thread, then insert the shank button and crochet the back in magenta (see page 62).

projects.finished_product_description: A magenta crocheted button with white French knots.

projects.name: Mandala Button

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in orange
very fine crochet yarn in blue
very fine crochet yarn in light green
very fine crochet yarn in magenta

steps.instruction: Cut off 60–70cm (23½–27½in) of the blue yarn for embroidering, and set aside. Crochet first to seventh rounds (see page 62), starting with blue. Crochet the third round in orange, the fourth and fifth in magenta, then one round in light green and one in orange. When changing colours, work the slip stitch at the end of the round in the new colour. Work the following round in blue with picots. Join the blue yarn at the end of the round with one slip stitch, * work three chain stitches, one single crochet (UK double crochet) in the first of the three chain stitches, miss one stitch, and work one single crochet (UK double crochet) into the front loop of the next stitch. Repeat from *. Close the round with one slip stitch in the first blue chain. Insert the shank button and crochet the back in blue (see page 62), working the first round in the back loops of the stitches in the seventh round in orange so that the blue picots protrude over the side of the button.

projects.finished_product_description: A multi-colored mandala-style crocheted button with blue picots.

projects.name: Flower Button

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in orange
very fine crochet yarn in blue
very fine crochet yarn in light green
very fine crochet yarn in magenta
very fine crochet yarn in burgundy

steps.instruction: Crochet the first to seventh rounds (see page 62): Start with orange and crochet two rounds. Then work one round each in blue, light green, magenta, orange and blue. When changing colours, work the last slip stitch in the round in the new colour. Increase the loop on the hook, but do not cut the blue yarn. Secure the ends, then sew on French knots and satin stitches in light green and magenta (see page 38). Insert the shank button and crochet the back in blue (see page 62).

Crochet the first to fourth rounds in orange (see page 62). Then crochet one round of picots in magenta. Join the magenta yarn at the end of the round with one slip stitch, * work three chain stitches, one single crochet (UK double crochet) in the first of the three chain stitches, miss one stitch, and work one single crochet (UK double crochet) into the front loop of the next stitch. Repeat from *. Finish the round with one slip stitch in the first slip stitch in magenta, then cut the yarn and draw through. Join burgundy to the back loop of a single crochet (UK double crochet) in orange and work one round as instructed, starting at the beginning of a round, repeating the pattern four times and finishing with one slip stitch in the chain. Work the back the same as the front but without the picots, and all in burgundy. Push the blank button shank through the opening before tightening the loop of thread. Place the front and back together (with the white coat button between) and join with one round of slip stitches. When you are about half way round, stuff the flower with wadding/batting and push into shape.

projects.finished_product_description: A multi-colored flower-shaped crocheted button with picots and French knots.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a pattern repeat for a crochet stitch, with symbols for 'Pattern repeat' and 'Beginning of round'. A note indicates 'Symbols see page 66'.

projects.name: Dog, Cat, Mouse Buttons

tools.name: sewing needle
tools.purpose: to pull out whiskers and secure thread

steps.instruction: The animal faces are crocheted on to plastic grid buttons, which are special transparent plastic buttons for sewing and crocheting. Crochet around the button to join the button top and bottom together. Join the yarn on an outside opening on the button. Observe the position of the shank in the crochet pattern to make sure that the hook eyes is more or less horizontal on the finished head; the shank should be facing down. Then work single crochet (UK double) into the opening as per the pattern and crochet on the ears.
steps.technique: crocheting around a plastic grid button
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a clear plastic grid button with crochet hook and green yarn working around the edge.

steps.instruction: The ears are crocheted on to the head and worked double to make sure they are firm and do not curl up. For the cat, for example, work six chain stitches for the front of the ear, then turn and work single crochet (UK double), half double (UK half treble) etc. into the chain stitch. Then work six more chain stitches for the back of the ear and continue crocheting to the double treble (UK triple treble).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a clear plastic grid button with crochet hook and green yarn, showing the beginning of an ear shape being crocheted.

steps.instruction: Fold over the back of the ear so that it is below the front part. For the mouse, you can work the loose links of four chains stitches onto the backs of the ears to match. The backs of the dog's ears are not folded over, but instead placed under the front parts of the ears. Like the fronts of the ears, the right sides of the backs point upwards.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a clear plastic grid button with crochet hook and green yarn, showing the ear being folded.

steps.instruction: Insert the hook into the front of the ear from above, take up the back loop (or chain) of the front and back parts of the ear, and work one slip stitch to join them (shown in grey).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a clear plastic grid button with crochet hook and green yarn, showing the ear being joined with a slip stitch.

steps.instruction: When the top of the button is finished, secure the ends of the black thread used for the nose, and sew on the mouth in backstitch. The tip of the dog's and mouse's nose points up, whereas the cat's points down. To make the whiskers, knot together three pieces of black thread about 20cm (7¾in) long in the middle with a double knot. Push the knot into the nose and pull the individual whiskers out using a sewing needle or crochet hook. Use black sewing thread and a sewing needle to secure the whisker knot on the inside.

Then sew on the beads for the eyes. Draw the needle out in the desired spot, thread the white and then the black bead; feed the thread back through the white bead, and push into the crochet. Repeat this process once more. Secure the thread on the inside, and sew on the second eye in the same way. Make sure the thread is well secured.

tips: Crochet them in any colour!
projects.finished_product_description: Adorable animal faces crocheted onto plastic grid buttons, with cute faces and loyal, loving eyes.

diagram_descriptions: Crochet diagram showing a circular pattern with numbered rounds (1, 2, 3) and various stitch symbols.
Crochet diagram showing a section of a pattern with numbered steps (2, 4) and stitch symbols, including a black triangle indicating a decrease.

projects.name: Crocheted Buttons

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in orange, white (for the mouse), light green (for the cat) and light blue (for the dog)
materials.color: orange, white, light green, light blue

materials.item: very fine crochet yarn in black

steps.instruction: Crochet around the plastic grid buttons, and crochet on the ears (see page 67 and crochet pattern below).
Work the faces as shown in the pattern, then start with a loop of black thread (see page 62).
At the end of round one, change to the face colour, and start by working the slip stitch in the new colour.
Draw the loop up at the end of the last round (do not cut) and complete the face (see page 67).
Place the face on the bottom of the button and crochet both together around the edge in slip stitches, catching one outside stitch loop on the top and the bottom in your work.
On the ears, crochet the top to the loops around the grid head or else to the doubles (UK trebles).
A few stitches before the end of the round, stuff the head with wadding/batting and press into shape.

projects.finished_product_description: Crocheted buttons in the shape of animal faces (mouse, cat, dog) attached to cards.

templates.shape_description: A circular pattern with radiating lines and stitches, starting with a central circle and black and orange dashed lines, transitioning to pink and orange stitches. templates.shape_description: A circular pattern with three ear shapes attached. The central part is a grey circular diagram with radiating lines and stitches. The ears are depicted as separate crochet patterns with green stitches, showing a progression of stitches and decreasing at the top.

templates.name: Pattern for the dog's ears
templates.shape_description: A circular pattern with three ear shapes attached. The central part is a grey circular diagram with radiating lines and stitches. The ears are depicted as separate crochet patterns with blue stitches, showing a progression of stitches and decreasing at the top.

templates.name: Pattern for the mouse's ears
templates.shape_description: A circular pattern with three ear shapes attached. The central part is a grey circular diagram with radiating lines and stitches. The ears are depicted as separate crochet patterns with orange stitches, showing a progression of stitches and decreasing at the top.

projects.name: Twiggy buttons

materials.notes: if using green wood, risk of splitting or rot

materials.item: small screw hooks or rivet pins

materials.notes: a little smaller than the hook thread or a little thicker than the rivet pin

steps.instruction: Pull the bark off the sticks. Saw the sticks to the size you want the buttons to be. Smooth the surfaces with the coarse sandpaper, then with the smoother sandpaper. Pre-drill a hole for the hook in the middle, then screw in the hook or drill a small hole through the piece of wood and push in the rivet pin and bend on the bottom to make a shank. Trim any overlapping material.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a small metal hook being screwed into it. Image 2 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a skewer inserted through a hook, and the wood is being painted white.

steps.instruction: Push the skewer or cocktail stick through the hook so that you can hold the button by it. Prime the button with white acrylic paint and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a skewer inserted through a hook, and the wood is being painted white.

steps.instruction: Draw on dots, lines or patterns with the paint markers. Before adding any overlapping layers, allow the bottom one to dry well first.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with purple dots being drawn on it with a marker. Image 4 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a fineliner drawing details and dots on a painted pattern.

steps.instruction: Once the paint is dry, draw the contours and tiny dots with the fineliner. Leave the button to dry and then varnish.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows a hand holding a piece of wood with a fineliner drawing details and dots on a painted pattern.

tips: Use screw punch for clean holes
projects.finished_product_description: Novel buttons made from driftwood, sticks, and small branches, decorated with paint markers and fineliner details.

diagram_descriptions: Image 1: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of wood and screwing a small metal hook into it.
Image 2: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of wood with a skewer inserted through a hook, and the wood is being painted white with a brush.
Image 3: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of wood and drawing purple dots on it with a marker.
Image 4: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of wood and using a black fineliner to draw details and tiny dots on a painted pattern.
Top right of the page shows several pieces of driftwood and a finished twiggy button with a pattern of purple and blue circles on a white background.

projects.name: Driftwood buttons

materials.dimensions: 0.4mm (US 26 guage) diameter or a little thicker than the rivet pin

steps.instruction: Drill a little hole through the wood a little off-centre (at the spot where you want to start winding) and thread the end of the wire through from the top to the bottom.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand holding a piece of driftwood and a thin wire being threaded through a small drilled hole.

steps.instruction: Wind it tightly around the piece of wood, perhaps including a bead in the middle of the winding on the top, and incorporating the split ring on the back. Push the bead and ring over the end of the wire, keeping the wire as straight as possible. You must not allow any bends or twists in the wire. In order to include the ring the second and third times, carefully pull the wire through the ring without letting it bend.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand winding gold wire around a piece of driftwood. A bead is shown being incorporated into the winding.

steps.instruction: Wind it tightly around the piece of wood, perhaps including a bead in the middle of the winding on the top, and incorporating the split ring on the back. Push the bead and ring over the end of the wire, keeping the wire as straight as possible. You must not allow any bends or twists in the wire. In order to include the ring the second and third times, carefully pull the wire through the ring without letting it bend.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand winding gold wire around a piece of driftwood, showing the wire being wrapped multiple times.

steps.instruction: Once you have wound enough wire around the wood, wrap it around the starting point of the ring a few times.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand wrapping the end of the gold wire around the base of the windings on a piece of driftwood.

steps.instruction: Twist the beginning and end of the wire together.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand twisting the beginning and end wires together on a piece of driftwood.

steps.instruction: Trim the ends of the wire and push them under the windings or ring.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hand trimming excess wire ends and tucking them under the windings on a driftwood button.

steps.instruction: Rivet pin version: drill a hole in the middle of the piece of wood. Push a piece of shell or bead cap onto the pin, then push the rivet pin through the wood and bend the bottom to make a shank. Trim any overlapping material.

projects.finished_product_description: Charming driftwood buttons with a beach holiday vibe, decorated with gold wire, beads, or shells.

projects.name: Clay Buttons

steps.instruction: Cut off a sufficient quantity of equally sized pieces of modelling clay. Kneading makes the clay soft and pliable. Many of these buttons are made by rolling a ball and then flattening it to make a circle or shaping into an oval. Be sure to use baking parchment as it's easy to pull the modelling clay off of after baking.
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows three pieces of white modelling clay, one rectangular and two cut into smaller pieces. Image 2 shows a finger pressing a split ring into a flattened piece of white modelling clay.

steps.instruction: If you want to attach a shank on the back of the button, push the ring into the clay in the middle of the back. Make a little tie, push it through the ring and smooth it with a knife.
steps.visual_description: Image 2 shows a finger pressing a split ring into a flattened piece of white modelling clay.

steps.instruction: To make the bird's head, start by flattening a ball of clay. For the beak, shape a piece about 2mm (1/16 in) thick with your hand and cut out one triangle.
steps.visual_description: Image 3 shows a piece of orange clay being cut into a triangle with a knife. A red piece of clay is also visible.

steps.instruction: To make the eyes, roll a little line of clay, flatten it slightly and cut two slices out of the middle. Cut the bottom edge off in a straight line. Place the beak and eyes on the head and press down. To make the pupils, roll a thin line of clay and cut off two tiny pieces, then shape into balls and position on the eyes.
steps.visual_description: Image 4 shows pieces of white clay cut into oval shapes for eyes and small rectangles for eyebrows. Image 5 shows a finished bird's head with beak and eyes, and small pieces of clay for pupils.

steps.instruction: Two little rolled up pieces of aluminium foil will keep the shank buttons in place when baking them. Shank buttons with a flat top can also be put face down on the baking parchment for baking.
steps.visual_description: Image 6 shows three finished clay bird buttons placed on crumpled aluminum foil.

tips: Be sure to use baking parchment as it's easy to pull the modelling clay off of after baking.
Two little rolled up pieces of aluminium foil will keep the shank buttons in place when baking them.
Shank buttons with a flat top can also be put face down on the baking parchment for baking.
projects.finished_product_description: Buttons made from modelling clay in various shapes and designs, including birds, hearts, and patterned circles.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up view of a wooden box filled with various buttons. The buttons include red and white striped buttons, mother-of-pearl buttons, buttons with carved patterns (flowers, eyes), blue buttons with white polka dots, and pink pig-shaped buttons.

projects.name: Modelling Clay Buttons

materials.color: white-transparent, yellow, orange, red (for Button A)
metallic blue, metallic white (for Button B)
metallic blue, metallic white, red, metallic grey (for Button C)
pink, white, black, red (for Pig Button)

tools.name: smooth sandpaper
tools.purpose: exposing original clay color on raised areas

steps.instruction: To make pieces of equal thickness, place the modelling clay between two wooden planks and roll out with the rolling pin. The clay will then be as thick as the planks.
steps.visual_description: A hand rolling red clay between two wooden planks using a wooden rolling pin.

steps.instruction: You can use almost any kind of stamp to make a relief-type surface. Either stamp a rolled out surface and then cut out the button, or shape a ball into the desired button and then stamp it.
steps.visual_description: A hand pressing a heart-shaped stamp onto a piece of red clay.

steps.instruction: Tiny beads and other buttons can also be used to make a pattern on the surface. Beads are easy to lift off again with a pin or needle as shown. If using shank buttons, attach the shank first and place the button on the two planks (which you have wrapped in aluminium foil) with the shank between the planks. Then decorate the button.
steps.visual_description: A hand using a pin/needle to lift a small bead from a white clay surface with flower patterns. Another image shows a hand pressing a white button shank into a grey clay oval with a textured pattern.

steps.instruction: Use the lid of a felt pen, skewers or a knife to create graphic patterns. Work all the way to the edge of the button by pressing in half motifs.
After baking (refer to the manufacturer's instructions), coat the buttons in clear varnish and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting white varnish onto a red heart-shaped button with a raised pattern.

steps.instruction: Then paint the surface in a contrasting colour (acrylic paint) and wipe off with a paper towel so that the paint only remains in the indentations. Apply another layer of clear varnish to the buttons. It is not possible to wipe all of the paint off unvarnished buttons: the whole button is painted, and the colour is much stronger in the indentations. If you like, you can use smooth sandpaper on the raised areas to expose the original colour of the button.
steps.visual_description: A hand wiping excess white paint from a red heart-shaped button with a cloth, leaving paint in indentations.

steps.instruction: For the striped buttons, roll very thin laces out on the baking parchment with flat hands. Place the laces on the rolled-out surface and push down with the rolling pin (running it over the two wooden battens).
steps.visual_description: A hand rolling a rolling pin over white stripes placed on a red clay piece between two wooden battens.

steps.instruction: Cut the desired number of pieces out of the various colours for buttons A and B. Roll the pieces into balls, then make them into ovals.
Attach the ring to the back (see page 74).
Cut little pieces off a rolled lace and shape into balls, then place on the button. Press very lightly on the balls so that they sit on the button like tiny nubs.
Roll the pieces into balls, then place in your cupped hand and shape into a hemisphere.
Attach the ring on the back and model the shape a little more if necessary.
Top with tiny white balls (see above) and press down flat.
Roll out one red piece and one blue piece, and place grey stripes on the red piece and white stripes on the blue one. Press down (see page 76).
Cut out the buttons with cutters, making sure the stripes are arranged as desired.
Smooth the edges with your fingers.
Varnish the buttons after baking.
Start with a large ball of pink for the face. Press the ball down flat.
Put on a small ball as the nose and press down flat.

To make the ears, squeeze together some little pieces of modelling clay on one side between your index finger and thumb to make a point. Add the ears, bending one if you like, and smooth the base of the ear with a knife.
Roll tiny laces for the eyes (one in white and one very thin one in black), cut off two pieces of the same size and roll into balls (see page 74). Put the balls on the face and press down.
You can decide whether you want the pig to be cross-eyed or have both eyes looking in a particular direction.
Add a red line of clay for the mouth, and use the skewer to make two nostril holes pierce all the way through so the head can be sewn on.

tips: Refer to manufacturer's instructions for baking oven-bake modelling clay.
Refer to page 74 for other tools and materials, and for instructions on rolling clay into balls.
